title: If there is no “I” after enlightenment, why do enlightened writers still speak in terms of “I”? - Quora

response.answer_text: In fact, there are different definitions of enlightenment that result from different forms of meditation and those definitions (like the effects of the different forms of meditation) can be exactly the opposite. For example, the definition of of the beginning stage of enlightenment in Transcendental Meditation is NOT that “I” goes away, but that I am becomes “pure” (after enlightenmetn, one doesn’t call desires or thoughts in the brain “my thoughts” or “my desires” — they are simply mental activity that exists in the brain that happens to be observable directly) and that pure I am becomes permanent: present whether one is awake, dreaming or in deep sleep: A list of many of the studies that have been done on the topics of TM, samadhi/pure consciousness and enlightenment can be found here. . As part of the studies on enlightenment via TM, researchers found 17 subjects (average meditation, etc experience 16,000 hours) who were reporting at least having a pure sense-of-self continuously for at least a year, and asked them to "describe yourself" (see table 3 of psychological correlates study), and these were some of the responses: We ordinarily think my self as this age; this color of hair; these hobbies . . . my experience is that my Self is a lot larger than that. It's immeasurably vast. . . on a physical level. It is not just restricted to this physical environmentIt's the ‘‘I am-ness.’’ It's my Being. There's just a channel underneath that's just underlying everything. It's my essence there and it just doesn't stop where I stop. . . by ‘‘I,’’ I mean this 5 ft. 2 person that moves around here and thereI look out and see this beautiful divine Intelligence. . . you could say in the sky, in the tree, but really being expressed through these things. . . and these are my SelfI experience myself as being without edges or content. . . beyond the universe. . . all-pervading, and being absolutely thrilled, absolutely delighted with every motion that my body makes. With everything that my eyes see, my ears hear, my nose smells. There's a delight in the sense that I am able to penetrate that. My consciousness, my intelligence pervades everything I see, feel and thinkWhen I say ’’I’’ that's the Self. There's a quality that is so pervasive about the Self that I'm quite sure that the ‘‘I’’ is the same ‘‘I’’ as everyone else's ‘‘I.’’ Not in terms of what follows right after. I am tall, I am short, I am fat, I am this, I am that. But the ‘‘I’’ part. The ‘‘I am’’ part is the same ‘‘I am’’ for you and meSo, for TM-style enlightenment, your question not only doesn’t make sense, but is exactly the opposite of what long-term TM does. One man’s enlightenment is another man’s ultimate delusion. It is up to you to decide which meditation tradition and so which enlightenment outcome is better for you.

The “I” continues to exist post-enlightenment. However, the perspective shifts such that a so-called enlightened being no longer identifies with the “I” perspective of the mind-body and identifies instead with a larger interconnected awareness or Self. The “I” is mind-generated and, in a sense, a virtual perspective of reality based upon sensory inputs and composite mental interpretations of one’s environment. It never actually existed except within the confines of an individual’s abstractions of events perceived and conceptualized by the mind-body complex. While enlightenment is described somewhat differently within various doctrines, it is essentially a deeply more subtle perspective of a more universal and direct awareness. It exists outside the confines of (though includes) thought, language and a perspective of a self. In Buddhism, this is referred to as anatta (Pali) or anatman (Sanskrit) or “no self”. Thus, confusion arises because if there is no self how can there be an “I”? This gets explained very cleverly by pointing out that the “I” was only an illusion of duality and therefore never existed in the first place. However, that cleverness doesn’t help if one is shopping for groceries, teaching children or running a company. Unless we choose to live out our existence isolated in a cave somewhere, we do live in duality - a consensual delusion. While we may realize that there is no objective physical reality beyond the interpretations of individual minds, the mind-body experience is the common human experience. Thus, we humans live in a synthetic reality whereby a discrete mind-body has learned to interact with other mind-bodies by agreement of defined concepts. One of those concepts is “I” and it is useful in navigating our co-created reality. In effect, the enlightened being recognizes and has access to both a provisional truth and an ultimate truth (two truths doctrine) and, with practice, can navigate freely within and between them. “I” is ultimately a useful instrument of language rather than an independent entity. /////

Try writing & speaking about enlightenment, or any part of life, without using the term “I,” and see what happens! Good luck with that. As other answerers have noted, it depends on your definition of “enlightenment,” as well as who referring to when you say “enlightened writers” Many of the most widely-accepted as fully enlightened writers of the past century - Sri Ramakrishna, Ramana Maharshi, Sri Nisargadhatta, Papaji, Jean Klein, etc. - have copious books and “writings,” but they did not actually write a word, and had no intention of putting out a book or claiming themselves as enlightened writers. Those books and writings are simply transcriptions of talks they gave, collected & published by one or more of their devoted followers. Nisargadhatta‘s “I Am That,” widely recognized as one of the greatest “books” about enlightenment, was simply a collection of the salient points he discussed in decades of giving humble Satsangs in his humble Bombay loft. And were you to read all 5 of the above, you would notice they almost never refer to themselves as “I.” Indeed they don’t talk much about themselves at all, but rather, just point to the awakening process. Similarly, when counseling others, I almost exclusively speak of the unfolding of awakening and the nameless Consciousness that is everything. I rarely bring up my own “personal story;” it’s about our story. Accordingly, I’ve gone out of my way to avoid the “I” term when talking about “enlightenment,” even when using my own unfolding to lend clarity to part of the “path.” I say, this took place in “this location” or “through this vessel” or this “seemingly-separate body-mind.” But that can also sound hokey and “new-agey” As long as we are playing out this temporary, illusory role of “separate” humans, living out this allotted time Consciousness manifested to express & experience something through these individual vessels, we are, and must speak as, both Pure Consciousness and a separate “I” at the same time. Even after realizing there is only One and becoming that One, when choosing to say “I am All of Conscioussness” or “I’m just me,” there’s nothing wrong with humbly choosing the latter.

Conventions of speech. One who is enlightened can still speak normally…they are just not fooled by the words used. One who is enlightened can say “I” knowing that it is the body/mind being referred to and no “I” really exists. I am writing this and you are reading it…this is just normal speech. But in reality there is no “I” or “you”…no such duality of separation exists. Duality is only an illusion. But do you think that the enlightened lose the ability to use pronouns and must create some new form of speech or not talk at all?

Language imposes limitations. It has a certain number of words that can be used to express, one has to choose the words that fit best, even if they don’t convey precisely what one wishes to say. Human mind imposes limitations. It has a certain number of concepts and structures which organize how it perceives reality. If one wishes to speak in such a way that a mind will understand, one has to speak within mind’s structures and concepts, even if they don’t convey precisely what one wishes to say. An adult speaking to child is a good example. An adult realizes that the child can only understand so much, so he will simplify what he has to say sufficiently for the child to be able to grasp it. He will speak in categories the child can understand, communicate only the bits and pieces that the child can absorb.

Because language was not created by the enlightened people. It was created by us. And they couldn’t create it even if they wanted to, because enlightenment happens in deep utter silence. It cannot be put into words. Still, words must be used. So when enlightened people speak, they use our language. But we must remember that the words are not adequate to the experience. “I” is a pronoun. When an ordinary person uses the word “I” he is referring to a sense of self he feels actually exists within him. A self which is the doer of things, the thinker of thoughts, the chooser of this and that, the seer, the hearer, a subjective sense of self.  When an enlightened person uses the word “I” he is referring to name and form and the stream of consciousness which the name and form are imputed on. He does so out of convenience because it sounds awkward and pretensious to not speak natural. There is no need to talk funny. An enlightened person still has a body, still has a mind, thoughts, etc. It is natural to use the word “I” when referring to these. It doesn’t mean that he feels there is an eternal ghost in the machine who controls all this.

We have a false self or ego, the “I” we believe we are, that is created by our mind based on our experiences in life since birth and our educational, cultural and religious beliefs. To truly find Self, our authentic Self we must face ego and dismantle it so it no longer rules and tells us who we think we are. Finding our authentic Self is where enlightenment begins…our false self creates duality with who we truly are which prevents true enlightenment. Removal of the falls self of “I” is what is being referred to.

If there is no “I” after enlightenment, why do enlightened writers still speak in terms of “I”? How does a human being write or speak without saying “I”? I don’t care if you’re enlightened or not. You’re still an individual. I challenge anyone to go without using the word “I.” Even if you’re talking about humanity in general, you’re often talking about yourself in relation to other humans. I don’t even want to try to communicate with anyone who never says “I.” No matter how immersed in the spiritual you are, you’re always going to be talking about how certain things made you feel. I meditated. I felt at one with the world. Just because a person becomes “enlightened” doesn’t mean that his or her personhood disappears.

Enlightenment is not the denial that you, your individual self exists. While you realize that your true self is much more than your individual self, which is but a part of your true self, you still recognize that you are bound to the mental and physical limits of your individual self, and hence when referring to this individual self, you would use “I”. To do otherwise would be very confusing.

It is a myth that there is no I. Wht exists after enlightenment is the I combined with the divine. Therefore, it is always the I and divine together after enlightenment. When an enlightened being says I, it means that I and my divine together.

If there is no “I” after enlightenment, why do enlightened writers still speak in terms of “I”? To know what Enlightenment is you first have to know what Being is because it is Being that is Enlightened.

What writing is being referred to? An enlightened writer would be the first to say that no one is writing and that there is no such thing as an enlightened writer. The paradox is that communication suggests a ‘you’ and a ‘me.’ But that is not so.
Linguistic habits and ease of readability. In some cases, due to reconfiguration of Personal Identity.
there is still the need to use language and a non specific reference to oneself is very hard and a poor relation to simply saying I
